lexUnit.name: wail.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to utter an extended high-pitched cry

sentence.text: The man pulled himself in after the stretcher , the doors were closed and the ambulance began to move off , its siren wailing mournfully .
A siren wailed and faded into the sounds of general traffic below prompting them to action .
An uncanny silence covered the village ; the voices of women hushed the children ; dogs wailed but were muzzled .
With sirens wailing and blue lights flashing the red fire engine sped through the city .
Together the band of women wailed and sang out , beating cymbals and drums .
Extras wailed and rhubarbed in a lukewarm pagan frenzy .
Somewhere in the hotel a woman wailed and broke china .
Children , woken by their mothers , cried or wailed as they were hurried from their small huts into the main lodge , to hide .
Some onboard klaxon wailed as though in pain at the effort .
A string orchestra wailed as if in torment .
You wept and wailed all the way through .
She recalled the docks , and the way the sea screamed and wailed like a soul in torment , throwing itself against the piers with a wild vengeance that struck terror into her young heart .
Now and then they passed a baby wailing outside a peeling front door in a battered pram .
Just for a moment she ignored the by now loud warning sirens wailing at the back of her mind .
You could hear them wailing above the noise of the aircraft . "
A squatting beggar wailed at us from his place beside an open sewer .
The child immediately began to wail .
